title: 106_hr4485
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2000" and authorizes appropriations. For fiscal year 2001, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,773,710,000. $2,813,500,000 is allocated for Research and Related Activities, with specific amounts for Biological Sciences, Computer and Information Science, Engineering, and Geosciences. For fiscal year 2001, the National Science Foundation is authorized $3,773,710,000. Specific allocations include $807,200,000 for Geosciences, $159,790,000 for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, $220,970,000 for United States Polar Research Programs, $62,600,000 for United States Antarctic Logistical Support Activities, and $119,230,000 for Integrative Activities. Additionally, $726,700,000 is allocated for Education and Human Resources, with $53,080,000 for Graduate Research Fellowships. For Graduate Research Fellowships, $65,340,000 is allocated. $160,890,000 is designated for Salaries and Expenses, with specific amounts for research equipment including EarthScope, Large Hadron Collider, Millimeter Array, National Ecological Observatory Network, and South Pole Station. Salaries and Expenses allocation breakdown for various activities: $4,000,000 for Research and Related Activities travel, $310,000 for Education and Human Resources travel, $159,000 for Budget, Finance, and Award Management travel, $182,000 for Information and Resources Management travel, $358,468 for the Office of the Director travel, and $1,075,000 for ethics activities under section 6. In fiscal year 2002, $3,887,291,000 is authorized for the National Science Foundation, with $2,880,683,000 allocated for Research and Related Activities. $6,280,000 is designated for the Office of Inspector General, and there are restrictions on the use of funds for travel expenses. In fiscal year 2002, $2,880,683,000 is allocated for Research and Related Activities at the National Science Foundation, with specific amounts designated for various fields including Biological Sciences, Computer and Information Science, Engineering, Geosciences, Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, and United States Polar Research Programs. In fiscal year 2002, $2,880,683,000 is allocated for Research and Related Activities at the National Science Foundation. Specific amounts are designated for various fields including Biological Sciences, Computer and Information Science, Engineering, Geosciences, Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, United States Polar Research Programs, Antarctic Logistical Support Activities, Integrative Activities, Education and Human Resources, Graduate Research Fellowships, Major Research Equipment like EarthScope and the Large Hadron Collider. $20,000,000 allocated for the National Ecological Observatory Network; $165,756,000 for Salaries and Expenses, including funds for travel in Research, Education, Budget, Finance, Award Management, and Information Management. In fiscal year 2003, $4,003,909,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the National Science Foundation. Within this allocation, $370,000 is designated for travel for the Office of the Director, $1,075,000 for ethics activities under section 6, and $6,430,000 for the Office of Inspector General. There are restrictions on the use of funds for travel expenses. In fiscal year 2003, the National Science Foundation is authorized $4,003,909,000. Specific allocations include $2,967,103,000 for Research and Related Activities, $766,755,000 for Education and Human Resources, and $92,700,000 for Major Research Equipment, with allocations for EarthScope, Large Hadron Collider, and National Ecological Observatory Network. In fiscal year 2004, the National Science Foundation is authorized $4,124,027,000. Specific allocations include $3,056,116,000 for Research and Related Activities, $789,757,000 for Education and Human Resources, and $95,481,000 for Major Research Equipment. Additionally, $170,728,000 is allocated for Salaries and Expenses, and $6,623,000 for the Office of Inspector General. In fiscal year 2004, the National Science Foundation is authorized specific allocations for Research Equipment, EarthScope, National Ecological Observatory Network, Salaries and Expenses, and the Office of Inspector General. Funds are limited to employ not more than 75 full-time equivalent positions in the Office of the Director for fiscal year 2001 or 2002. SEC. 3. PLANT GENOMICS. The National Science Foundation can provide grants for regional plant genome and gene expression research centers to develop basic plant genome research, accelerate its application to crop improvement, and serve as scientific information hubs. Grant awards will be given through a competitive process to ensure representation of various agronomic environments. The National Science Foundation can provide grants for regional plant genome and gene expression research centers to develop basic plant genome research, accelerate its application to crop improvement, and serve as scientific information hubs. Grant awards will be given through a competitive process to ensure representation of various agronomic environments. The NSF shall not provide more than 50 percent of the cost of establishing any research and development center. Funds authorized for fiscal years 2001 to 2004 can be used to carry out this section. SEC. 4. RESEARCH ON LEARNING. The National Science Foundation will provide grant awards for research on learning in four key areas: brain research, behavioral and cognitive aspects of learning, STEM learning in formal and informal settings, and learning in complex educational systems. The research aims to integrate scientific disciplines, understand the connection between research and education, and test hypotheses across disciplines. The National Science Foundation will allocate funds for the establishment of research centers on learning to support multidisciplinary teams of researchers. Grant awards will be given through a competitive process. The National Science Foundation will allocate funds for research centers on learning through a competitive process. $6,000,000 to $9,000,000 for fiscal years 2001-2004 will be available. Additionally, the Interagency Education Research Initiative will receive $25,000,000 to $34,000,000 for fiscal years 2001-2004. Within 6 months of enacting this Act, the National Science Foundation will host a conference on human learning and education research. Researchers from various disciplines will gather to review past research, assess current efforts, and make recommendations to address research issues and share results with education practitioners. SEC. 5. The National Science Foundation will no longer detail employees to locations outside of its facilities under the Intergovernmental Personnel Act of 1970. SEC. 6. An ethics program will be implemented. The Director of the National Science Foundation will establish a program for external review and revision of ethics rules, as well as training employees on these revised procedures. Reports on employee training will be submitted to Congress every 6 months. The National Science Foundation will establish a program for external review and revision of ethics rules, as well as training employees. Reports on employee training and ethics violations will be submitted to Congress every 6 months. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. The National Science Foundation Act of 1950 is amended to update various sections. SEC. 8. REPORTS ELIMINATION. Section 3003(a)(1) of the Federal Reports Elimination and Sunset Act of 1995 does not apply to reports required under specific provisions of laws related to the National Science Foundation and High-Performance Computing. Section 7(a) of the National Science Foundation Authorization Act, 1977 (42 U.S.C. 1873 note) is referenced.
